messageBody:
:-)

I was thinking about that right after my last post.

The short answer is that I like the Class to be
focused on what it's supposed to do. So if all it
does is execute a command with an execute() method,
then that's the only method on the Class.

The reason I like the Class + ClassHelper pattern is
because
I'm treating the ClassHelper as a utility library that
is specific to Class.

It makes it clear that ClassHelper is there to assist
Class and only Class.

Then once I'm done creating Class and ClassHelper, I
look for ways to put ClassHelper methods in a Utility
library.

I find this helpful when coding command objects for
instance.

The Command Class only has a single method execute().

I code a helper with lots of little methods that help
the command do its job.

Then later on myself, and others, working with the
commands can look for opportunities to centralize the
Helper methods in a utility library.

Cheers,
- Ole



--- Yagiz Erkan <yagizerkan@...> wrote:
